For the reasons I have explained, in the end host countries need to make the judgments on the   tradeoffs between these goals.  But I have also explained how a strong set of international   prudential standards and good institutional relationships among regulators could help tilt this   balance toward greater flexibility for internationally active banks.    In response to positions akin to what I have presented today, one often hears complaints   that the emphasis on financial stability will result in the balkanization of international banking.  I   would note first that it is not at all clear that developments since the crisis have on net balkanized   banking, so much as shifted some international banking assets from the Organisation for   Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) countries whose banks were   disproportionately affected by the financial crisis to banks from some emerging market and   developing countries.13  This development probably reflects both needed changes in some of the   OECD nation banks and a logical reflection of the increasing economic importance of the non-  OECD countries.      Second, I wonder how these critics can think that the pre-crisis situation of supposedly   consolidated oversight and substantial bank flexibility was a desirable one.
